thread.title: Victorian government, Google pointing fingers over public transport fail
thread.title_full: Victorian government, Google pointing fingers over public transport fail

title: Victorian government, Google pointing fingers over public transport fail
text:
Google Maps: No routes found Photo: Reddit
Melbourne still has not got public transport directions on Google Maps, with Public Transport Victoria and search giant Google stuck in an embarrassing impasse with plenty of finger-pointing going on.
The new Labor government promised way back in January to hand public transport timetable information to Google so it could incorporate it into Google Maps. Every other capital city in Australia has the service.
Ten months later and Google and PTV are both blaming each other for a stuff-up with the data.
"The data provided by PTV doesn't currently meet the quality requirements for Google Transit," a spokesman for Google told The Age .
Advertisement "PTV and Google continue to work together to fast-track the availability of transport information in Victoria."
In March 2015, some six months ago, Premier Daniel Andrews announced on Reddit Google Maps integration was on its way.
In correspondence this month with user Phillip Malone, who was complaining about the lack of public transport directions, Google expanded on the problem. Mr Malone later posted the exchange on Facebook .
"The folks from PTV have provided us with their transit information. However, currently we are facing a block due to which the process to integrate their data on Maps is being shelved temporarily.
"We are trying our best to improve the quality of the GTFS (general transit feed specification) feed and to ensure that it conforms with the GTFS. At this point, it is difficult to assume when the feed will be ready for production. But please understand, we are exploring options to make the data live soon."
GTFS is a data format for public transportation timetables and associated geographic information.
Public Transport Victoria has a very different take. The agency says it's all Google's fault.
"It is Victorian government policy to release relevant data in a format that is accessible for everyone, not in formats specified by individual organisations and developers," a spokesman for the agency told The Age .
"PTV released its timetable data in GTFS format on 1 April, 2015, and this is being used by Triptastic, Travic, Bing and here.com in their digital applications and websites.
"Google has additional data requirements beyond GTFS for its transit application, and PTV is working with Google to provide that data in a timely manner."
Whoever is at fault, the impasse is depriving Victorians of access to a service the rest of Australia takes for granted.
Google uses the GTFS data format to allow timetable data – stop locations, timetables, route maps – into Google Maps, which comes standard on many mobile phones.
With Melbourne's GTFS incorporated, Melburnians would be able to select two points on a map and have Google plan a bus, tram and train journey for them.
Melbourne has had a long and troubled relationship with GTFS data. Public Transport Victoria for years refused to release the data in GTFS format, claiming that other data formats were just fine.
Then, finally, the new Labor government announced the data would be reformatted to GTFS and released. But it seems even that has not been enough.
